Constructor & Destructor Documentation

App::App (  ) 

Default constructor for test loader creates model to draw and then sets up the camera and such

There is a template for a class called DispatchKey (hence why you pass GUI in <>) it accepts in its constructor a pointer to a class of type whatever you passed in as the template. The 2nd param is a reference to the member function that you want to be executed. This is tricky because the result is going to be specificly typed to be "DispatchKey<GUI>" which is not what we want. So, take the resulting object which is a reference to the object. Since this is a pointer it can be stored as an int. Ints are allowed in a vector, so what we are doing is type casting a pointer to an int so that we can hold a lot of unsimilar types in an array then when we need to call them we type cast them back to a type that we know (GUI in this case) so that we can dispatch our event to them, which will most likely be dispatched to another system.

In this case we are dispatching the generic key catcher for the GUI class, this will sub-dispatch to all GUI elements that it has so that they can do their magic.
